an4.163:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are four ways of practice.

an4.163:1.5.eng: pleasant practice with slow insight, and

an4.163:2.1.pli: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, dukkhā paṭipadā dandhābhiññā?
an4.163:2.1.eng: And what’s the painful practice with slow insight?

an4.163:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu asubhānupassī kāye viharati, āhāre paṭikūlasaññī, sabbaloke anabhiratisaññī, sabbasaṅkhāresu aniccānupassī;
an4.163:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates observing the ugliness of the body, perceives the repulsiveness of food, perceives dissatisfaction with the whole world, observes the impermanence of all conditions,

an4.163:2.3.pli: maraṇasaññā kho panassa ajjhattaṃ sūpaṭṭhitā hoti.
an4.163:2.3.eng: and has well established the perception of their own death.

an4.163:2.4.pli: So imāni pañca sekhabalāni upanissāya viharati—
an4.163:2.4.eng: They rely on these five powers of a trainee:

an4.163:2.5.eng: faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom.

an4.163:2.6.eng: But these five faculties manifest in them weakly:

an4.163:2.7.eng: faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

an4.163:2.8.pli: So imesaṃ pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ muduttā dandhaṃ ānantariyaṃ pāpuṇāti āsavānaṃ khayāya.
an4.163:2.8.eng: Because of this, they only slowly attain the conditions for ending the defilements in the present life.

an4.163:2.9.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, dukkhā paṭipadā dandhābhiññā.
an4.163:2.9.eng: This is called the painful practice with slow insight.

an4.163:3.1.pli: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, dukkhā paṭipadā khippābhiññā?
an4.163:3.1.eng: And what’s the painful practice with swift insight?

an4.163:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu asubhānupassī kāye viharati, āhāre paṭikūlasaññī, sabbaloke anabhiratisaññī, sabbasaṅkhāresu aniccānupassī;
an4.163:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates observing the ugliness of the body, perceives the repulsiveness of food, perceives dissatisfaction with the whole world, observes the impermanence of all conditions,

an4.163:3.3.pli: maraṇasaññā kho panassa ajjhattaṃ sūpaṭṭhitā hoti.
an4.163:3.3.eng: and has well established the perception of their own death.

an4.163:3.4.pli: So imāni pañca sekhabalāni upanissāya viharati—
an4.163:3.4.eng: They rely on these five powers of a trainee:

an4.163:3.5.eng: faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom.

an4.163:3.6.eng: And these five faculties manifest in them strongly:

an4.163:3.7.eng: faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

an4.163:3.8.pli: So imesaṃ pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ adhimattattā khippaṃ ānantariyaṃ pāpuṇāti āsavānaṃ khayāya.
an4.163:3.8.eng: Because of this, they swiftly attain the conditions for ending the defilements in the present life.

an4.163:3.9.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, dukkhā paṭipadā khippābhiññā.
an4.163:3.9.eng: This is called the painful practice with swift insight.

an4.163:4.1.pli: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, sukhā paṭipadā dandhābhiññā?
an4.163:4.1.eng: And what’s the pleasant practice with slow insight?

an4.163:4.2.pli: Idha bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati;
an4.163:4.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

an4.163:4.3.pli: vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati;
an4.163:4.3.eng: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

an4.163:4.4.pli: pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sato ca sampajāno sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedeti yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati;
an4.163:4.4.eng: And with the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

an4.163:4.5.pli: sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an4.163:4.5.eng: With the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

an4.163:4.6.pli: So imāni pañca sekhabalāni upanissāya viharati—
an4.163:4.6.eng: They rely on these five powers of a trainee:

an4.163:4.7.eng: faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom.

an4.163:4.8.eng: But these five faculties manifest in them weakly:

an4.163:4.9.eng: faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

an4.163:4.10.pli: So imesaṃ pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ muduttā dandhaṃ ānantariyaṃ pāpuṇāti āsavānaṃ khayāya.
an4.163:4.10.eng: Because of this, they only slowly attain the conditions for ending the defilements in the present life.

an4.163:4.11.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, sukhā paṭipadā dandhābhiññā.
an4.163:4.11.eng: This is called the pleasant practice with slow insight.

an4.163:5.1.pli: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, sukhā paṭipadā khippābhiññā?
an4.163:5.1.eng: And what’s the pleasant practice with swift insight?

an4.163:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati …pe… dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ …pe… tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ …pe… catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an4.163:5.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant … enters and remains in the first absorption … second absorption … third absorption … fourth absorption …

an4.163:5.3.pli: So imāni pañca sekhabalāni upanissāya viharati—
an4.163:5.3.eng: They rely on these five powers of a trainee:

an4.163:5.4.eng: faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom.

an4.163:5.5.eng: And these five faculties manifest in them strongly:

an4.163:5.6.eng: faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

an4.163:5.7.pli: So imesaṃ pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ adhimattattā khippaṃ ānantariyaṃ pāpuṇāti āsavānaṃ khayāya.
an4.163:5.7.eng: Because of this, they swiftly attain the conditions for ending the defilements in the present life.

an4.163:5.8.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, sukhā paṭipadā khippābhiññā.
an4.163:5.8.eng: This is called the pleasant practice with swift insight.

an4.163:5.9.eng: These are the four ways of practice.”

an4.164:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are four ways of practice.

an4.164:1.3.pli: Akkhamā paṭipadā, khamā paṭipadā, damā paṭipadā, samā paṭipadā.
an4.164:1.3.eng: Impatient practice, patient practice, taming practice, and calming practice.

an4.164:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco akkosantaṃ paccakkosati, rosantaṃ paṭirosati, bhaṇḍantaṃ paṭibhaṇḍati.
an4.164:1.5.eng: It’s when someone abuses, annoys, or argues with you, and you abuse, annoy, or argue right back at them.

an4.164:1.6.eng: This is called the impatient practice.

an4.164:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco akkosantaṃ na paccakkosati, rosantaṃ na paṭirosati, bhaṇḍantaṃ na paṭibhaṇḍati.
an4.164:2.2.eng: It’s when someone abuses, annoys, or argues with you, and you don’t abuse, annoy, or argue back at them.

an4.164:2.3.eng: This is called the patient practice.

an4.164:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī;
an4.164:3.2.eng: When a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.

an4.164:3.3.pli: yatvādhikaraṇamenaṃ cakkhundriyaṃ asaṃvutaṃ viharantaṃ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṃ, tassa saṃvarāya paṭipajjati; rakkhati cakkhundriyaṃ; cakkhundriye saṃvaraṃ āpajjati.
an4.164:3.3.eng: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving restraint over it.

an4.164:3.4.eng: When they hear a sound with their ears …

an4.164:3.5.eng: When they smell an odor with their nose …

an4.164:3.6.eng: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …

an4.164:3.7.eng: When they feel a touch with their body …

an4.164:3.8.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī;
an4.164:3.8.eng: When they know an idea with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.

an4.164:3.9.pli: yatvādhikaraṇamenaṃ manindriyaṃ asaṃvutaṃ viharantaṃ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṃ, tassa saṃvarāya paṭipajjati; rakkhati manindriyaṃ; manindriye saṃvaraṃ āpajjati.
an4.164:3.9.eng: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving restraint over it.

an4.164:3.10.eng: This is called the taming practice.

an4.164:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu uppannaṃ kāmavitakkaṃ nādhivāseti pajahati vinodeti sameti byantīkaroti anabhāvaṃ gameti; uppannaṃ byāpādavitakkaṃ …pe… uppannaṃ vihiṃsāvitakkaṃ … uppannuppanne pāpake akusale dhamme nādhivāseti pajahati vinodeti sameti byantīkaroti anabhāvaṃ gameti.
an4.164:4.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t tolerate a sensual, malicious, or cruel thought. They don’t tolerate any bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen, but give them up, get rid of them, calm them, eliminate them, and obliterate them.

an4.164:4.3.eng: This is called the calming practice.

an4.164:4.4.eng: These are the four ways of practice.”

an4.165:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are four ways of practice.

an4.165:1.3.pli: Akkhamā paṭipadā, khamā paṭipadā, damā paṭipadā, samā paṭipadā.
an4.165:1.3.eng: Impatient practice, patient practice, taming practice, and calming practice.

an4.165:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco akkhamo hoti sītassa uṇhassa jighacchāya pipāsāya, ḍaṃsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphassānaṃ duruttānaṃ durāgatānaṃ vacanapathānaṃ uppannānaṃ sārīrikānaṃ vedanānaṃ dukkhānaṃ tibbānaṃ kharānaṃ kaṭukānaṃ asātānaṃ amanāpānaṃ pāṇaharānaṃ anadhivāsakajātiko hoti.
an4.165:2.2.eng: It’s when someone cannot endure cold, heat, hunger, and thirst. They cannot endure the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles. They cannot endure rude and unwelcome criticism. And they cannot put up with physical pain—sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, disagreeable, and life-threatening.

an4.165:2.3.eng: This is called the impatient practice.

an4.165:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco khamo hoti sītassa uṇhassa jighacchāya pipāsāya, ḍaṃsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphassānaṃ duruttānaṃ durāgatānaṃ vacanapathānaṃ uppannānaṃ sārīrikānaṃ vedanānaṃ dukkhānaṃ tibbānaṃ kharānaṃ kaṭukānaṃ asātānaṃ amanāpānaṃ pāṇaharānaṃ adhivāsakajātiko hoti.
an4.165:3.2.eng: It’s when someone endures cold, heat, hunger, and thirst. They endure the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles. They endure rude and unwelcome criticism. And they put up with physical pain—sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, disagreeable, and life-threatening.

an4.165:3.3.eng: This is called the patient practice.

an4.165:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā na nimittaggāhī hoti …pe…
an4.165:4.2.eng: When a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details. …

an4.165:4.3.eng: When they hear a sound with their ears …

an4.165:4.4.eng: When they smell an odor with their nose …

an4.165:4.5.eng: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …

an4.165:4.6.eng: When they feel a touch with their body …

an4.165:4.7.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī;
an4.165:4.7.eng: When they know an idea with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.

an4.165:4.8.pli: yatvādhikaraṇamenaṃ manindriyaṃ asaṃvutaṃ viharantaṃ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṃ, tassa saṃvarāya paṭipajjati; rakkhati manindriyaṃ; manindriye saṃvaraṃ āpajjati.
an4.165:4.8.eng: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving restraint over it.

an4.165:4.9.eng: This is called the taming practice.

an4.165:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu uppannaṃ kāmavitakkaṃ nādhivāseti pajahati vinodeti sameti byantīkaroti anabhāvaṃ gameti, uppannaṃ byāpādavitakkaṃ …pe… uppannaṃ vihiṃsāvitakkaṃ … uppannuppanne pāpake akusale dhamme nādhivāseti pajahati vinodeti sameti byantīkaroti anabhāvaṃ gameti.
an4.165:5.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t tolerate a sensual, malicious, or cruel thought. They don’t tolerate any bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen, but give them up, get rid of them, calm them, eliminate them, and obliterate them.

an4.165:5.3.eng: This is called the calming practice.

an4.165:5.4.eng: These are the four ways of practice.”

an4.166:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are four ways of practice.

an4.166:1.5.eng: pleasant practice with slow insight, and

an4.166:2.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yāyaṃ paṭipadā dukkhā dandhābhiññā, ayaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭipadā ubhayeneva hīnā akkhāyati. Yampāyaṃ paṭipadā dukkhā, imināpāyaṃ hīnā akkhāyati; yampāyaṃ paṭipadā dandhā, imināpāyaṃ hīnā akkhāyati.
an4.166:2.1.eng: Of these, the painful practice with slow insight is said to be inferior in both ways: because it’s painful and because it’s slow.

an4.166:2.2.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭipadā ubhayeneva hīnā akkhāyati.
an4.166:2.2.eng: This practice is said to be inferior in both ways.

an4.166:3.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yāyaṃ paṭipadā dukkhā khippābhiññā, ayaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭipadā dukkhattā hīnā akkhāyati.
an4.166:3.1.eng: The painful practice with swift insight is said to be inferior because it’s painful.

an4.166:4.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yāyaṃ paṭipadā sukhā dandhābhiññā, ayaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭipadā dandhattā hīnā akkhāyati.
an4.166:4.1.eng: The pleasant practice with slow insight is said to be inferior because it’s slow.

an4.166:5.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yāyaṃ paṭipadā sukhā khippābhiññā, ayaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭipadā ubhayeneva paṇītā akkhāyati. Yampāyaṃ paṭipadā sukhā, imināpāyaṃ paṇītā akkhāyati; yampāyaṃ paṭipadā khippā, imināpāyaṃ paṇītā akkhāyati.
an4.166:5.1.eng: The pleasant practice with swift insight is said to be superior in both ways: because it’s pleasant, and because it’s swift.

an4.166:5.2.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭipadā ubhayeneva paṇītā akkhāyati.
an4.166:5.2.eng: This practice is said to be superior in both ways.

an4.166:5.3.eng: These are the four ways of practice.”

an4.167:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto yenāyasmā mahāmoggallāno tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā mahāmoggallānena saddhiṃ sammodi.
an4.167:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Sāriputta went up to Venerable Mahāmoggallāna, and exchanged greetings with him.

an4.167:1.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā sāriputto āyasmantaṃ mahāmoggallānaṃ etadavoca:
an4.167:1.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, Sāriputta sat down to one side and said to Mahāmoggallāna:

an4.167:2.1.eng: “Reverend Moggallāna, there are four ways of practice.

an4.167:2.5.eng: pleasant practice with slow insight, and

an4.167:2.7.eng: These are the four ways of practice.

an4.167:2.8.pli: Imāsaṃ, āvuso, catunnaṃ paṭipadānaṃ katamaṃ te paṭipadaṃ āgamma anupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimuttan”ti?
an4.167:2.8.eng: Which one of these four ways of practice did you rely on to free your mind from defilements by not grasping?”

an4.167:3.3.pli: Dukkhā paṭipadā dandhābhiññā, dukkhā paṭipadā khippābhiññā, sukhā paṭipadā dandhābhiññā, sukhā paṭipadā khippābhiññā.

an4.167:3.5.pli: Imāsaṃ, āvuso, catunnaṃ paṭipadānaṃ yāyaṃ paṭipadā dukkhā khippābhiññā, imaṃ me paṭipadaṃ āgamma anupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimuttan”ti.
an4.167:3.5.eng: I relied on the painful practice with swift insight to free my mind from defilements by not grasping.”

an4.168:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā sāriputtena saddhiṃ sammodi.
an4.168:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Mahāmoggallāna went up to Venerable Sāriputta, and exchanged greetings with him.

an4.168:1.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavoca:
an4.168:1.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, Mahāmoggallāna sat down to one side, and said to Sāriputta:

an4.168:2.1.eng: “Reverend Sāriputta, there are four ways of practice.

an4.168:2.5.eng: pleasant practice with slow insight, and

an4.168:2.7.eng: These are the four ways of practice.

an4.168:2.8.pli: Imāsaṃ, āvuso, catunnaṃ paṭipadānaṃ katamaṃ te paṭipadaṃ āgamma anupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimuttan”ti?
an4.168:2.8.eng: Which one of these four ways of practice did you rely on to free your mind from defilements by not grasping?”

an4.168:3.3.pli: Dukkhā paṭipadā dandhābhiññā, dukkhā paṭipadā khippābhiññā, sukhā paṭipadā dandhābhiññā, sukhā paṭipadā khippābhiññā.

an4.168:3.5.pli: Imāsaṃ, āvuso, catunnaṃ paṭipadānaṃ yāyaṃ paṭipadā sukhā khippābhiññā, imaṃ me paṭipadaṃ āgamma anupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimuttan”ti.
an4.168:3.5.eng: I relied on the pleasant practice with swift insight to free my mind from defilements by not grasping.”

an4.169:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these four individuals are found in the world.

an4.169:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo diṭṭheva dhamme sasaṅkhāraparinibbāyī hoti.
an4.169:1.3.eng: One individual is fully extinguished in this very life by making extra effort.

an4.169:1.4.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo kāyassa bhedā sasaṅkhāraparinibbāyī hoti.
an4.169:1.4.eng: One individual is fully extinguished when the body breaks up by making extra effort.

an4.169:1.5.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo diṭṭheva dhamme asaṅkhāraparinibbāyī hoti.
an4.169:1.5.eng: One individual is fully extinguished in this very life without making extra effort.

an4.169:1.6.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo kāyassa bhedā asaṅkhāraparinibbāyī hoti.
an4.169:1.6.eng: One individual is fully extinguished when the body breaks up without making extra effort.

an4.169:2.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, puggalo diṭṭheva dhamme sasaṅkhāraparinibbāyī hoti?
an4.169:2.1.eng: And how is an individual fully extinguished in this very life by making extra effort?

an4.169:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu asubhānupassī kāye viharati, āhāre paṭikūlasaññī, sabbaloke anabhiratisaññī, sabbasaṅkhāresu aniccānupassī.
an4.169:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates observing the ugliness of the body, perceives the repulsiveness of food, perceives dissatisfaction with the whole world, observes the impermanence of all conditions,

an4.169:2.3.pli: Maraṇasaññā kho panassa ajjhattaṃ sūpaṭṭhitā hoti.
an4.169:2.3.eng: and has well established the perception of their own death.

an4.169:2.4.pli: So imāni pañca sekhabalāni upanissāya viharati—
an4.169:2.4.eng: They rely on these five powers of a trainee:

an4.169:2.5.eng: faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom.

an4.169:2.6.eng: And these five faculties manifest in them strongly:

an4.169:2.7.eng: faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

an4.169:2.8.pli: So imesaṃ pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ adhimattattā diṭṭheva dhamme sasaṅkhāraparinibbāyī hoti.
an4.169:2.8.eng: Because of the strength of the five faculties, they are fully extinguished in this very life by making extra effort.

an4.169:2.9.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, puggalo diṭṭheva dhamme sasaṅkhāraparinibbāyī hoti.
an4.169:2.9.eng: That’s how an individual is fully extinguished in this very life by making extra effort.

an4.169:3.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, puggalo kāyassa bhedā sasaṅkhāraparinibbāyī hoti?
an4.169:3.1.eng: How is an individual fully extinguished when the body breaks up by making extra effort?

an4.169:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu asubhānupassī kāye viharati, āhāre paṭikūlasaññī, sabbaloke anabhiratisaññī, sabbasaṅkhāresu aniccānupassī.
an4.169:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates observing the ugliness of the body, perceives the repulsiveness of food, perceives dissatisfaction with the whole world, observes the impermanence of all conditions,

an4.169:3.3.pli: Maraṇasaññā kho panassa ajjhattaṃ sūpaṭṭhitā hoti.
an4.169:3.3.eng: and has well established the perception of their own death.

an4.169:3.4.pli: So imāni pañca sekhabalāni upanissāya viharati—
an4.169:3.4.eng: They rely on these five powers of a trainee:

an4.169:3.5.eng: faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom.

an4.169:3.6.eng: But these five faculties manifest in them weakly:

an4.169:3.7.eng: faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

an4.169:3.8.pli: So imesaṃ pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ muduttā kāyassa bhedā sasaṅkhāraparinibbāyī hoti.
an4.169:3.8.eng: Because of the weakness of the five faculties, they are fully extinguished when the body breaks up by making extra effort.

an4.169:3.9.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, puggalo kāyassa bhedā sasaṅkhāraparinibbāyī hoti.
an4.169:3.9.eng: That’s how an individual is fully extinguished when the body breaks up by making extra effort.

an4.169:4.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, puggalo diṭṭheva dhamme asaṅkhāraparinibbāyī hoti?
an4.169:4.1.eng: And how is an individual fully extinguished in this very life without making extra effort?

an4.169:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ …pe… dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ …pe… tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ …pe… catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an4.169:4.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant … enters and remains in the first absorption … second absorption … third absorption … fourth absorption …

an4.169:4.3.pli: So imāni pañca sekhabalāni upanissāya viharati—
an4.169:4.3.eng: They rely on these five powers of a trainee:

an4.169:4.4.eng: faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom.

an4.169:4.5.eng: And these five faculties manifest in them strongly:

an4.169:4.6.eng: faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

an4.169:4.7.pli: So imesaṃ pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ adhimattattā diṭṭheva dhamme asaṅkhāraparinibbāyī hoti.
an4.169:4.7.eng: Because of the strength of the five faculties, they are fully extinguished in this very life without making extra effort.

an4.169:4.8.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, puggalo diṭṭheva dhamme asaṅkhāraparinibbāyī hoti.
an4.169:4.8.eng: That’s how an individual is fully extinguished in this very life without making extra effort.

an4.169:5.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, puggalo kāyassa bhedā asaṅkhāraparinibbāyī hoti?
an4.169:5.1.eng: And how is an individual fully extinguished when the body breaks up without making extra effort?

an4.169:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ …pe… dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ …pe… tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ …pe… catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an4.169:5.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant … enters and remains in the first absorption … second absorption … third absorption … fourth absorption …

an4.169:5.3.pli: So imāni pañca sekhabalāni upanissāya viharati—
an4.169:5.3.eng: They rely on these five powers of a trainee:

an4.169:5.4.eng: faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom.

an4.169:5.5.eng: But these five faculties manifest in them weakly: faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

an4.169:5.6.pli: So imesaṃ pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ muduttā kāyassa bhedā asaṅkhāraparinibbāyī hoti.
an4.169:5.6.eng: Because of the weakness of the five faculties, they are fully extinguished when the body breaks up without making extra effort.

an4.169:5.7.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, puggalo kāyassa bhedā asaṅkhāraparinibbāyī hoti.
an4.169:5.7.eng: That’s how an individual is fully extinguished when the body breaks up without making extra effort.

an4.169:5.8.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmin”ti.
an4.169:5.8.eng: These are the four individuals found in the world.”

an4.17:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four ways of making prejudiced decisions.

an4.17:1.3.pli: Chandāgatiṃ gacchati, dosāgatiṃ gacchati, mohāgatiṃ gacchati, bhayāgatiṃ gacchati—
an4.17:1.3.eng: Making decisions prejudiced by favoritism, hostility, stupidity, and cowardice.

an4.17:1.4.eng: These are the four ways of making prejudiced decisions.

an4.17:2.1.eng: If you act against the teaching

an4.17:2.2.eng: out of favoritism, hostility, cowardice, or stupidity,

an4.17:2.4.eng: like the moon in the waning fortnight.”

an4.170:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ānando kosambiyaṃ viharati ghositārāme.
an4.170:1.2.eng: At one time Venerable Ānanda was staying near Kosambī, in Ghosita’s Monastery.

an4.170:1.3.pli: Tatra kho āyasmā ānando bhikkhū āmantesi:

an4.170:1.5.pli: “Āvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato ānandassa paccassosuṃ.

an4.170:2.1.pli: “Yo hi koci, āvuso, bhikkhu vā bhikkhunī vā mama santike arahattappattiṃ byākaroti, sabbo so catūhi maggehi, etesaṃ vā aññatarena.
an4.170:2.1.eng: “Reverends, all of the monks and nuns who declare in my presence that they have attained perfection, did so by one or other of four paths.

an4.170:3.2.pli: Idha, āvuso, bhikkhu samathapubbaṅgamaṃ vipassanaṃ bhāveti.
an4.170:3.2.eng: Take a mendicant who develops serenity before discernment.

an4.170:3.3.pli: Tassa samathapubbaṅgamaṃ vipassanaṃ bhāvayato maggo sañjāyati.
an4.170:3.3.eng: As they do so, the path is born in them.

an4.170:3.4.pli: So taṃ maggaṃ āsevati bhāveti bahulīkaroti.
an4.170:3.4.eng: They cultivate, develop, and make much of it.

an4.170:3.5.pli: Tassa taṃ maggaṃ āsevato bhāvayato bahulīkaroto saṃyojanāni pahīyanti, anusayā byantīhonti.
an4.170:3.5.eng: By doing so, they give up the fetters and eliminate the underlying tendencies.

an4.170:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu vipassanāpubbaṅgamaṃ samathaṃ bhāveti.
an4.170:4.1.eng: Another mendicant develops discernment before serenity.

an4.170:4.2.pli: Tassa vipassanāpubbaṅgamaṃ samathaṃ bhāvayato maggo sañjāyati.
an4.170:4.2.eng: As they do so, the path is born in them.

an4.170:4.3.pli: So taṃ maggaṃ āsevati bhāveti bahulīkaroti.
an4.170:4.3.eng: They cultivate, develop, and make much of it.

an4.170:4.4.pli: Tassa taṃ maggaṃ āsevato bhāvayato bahulīkaroto saṃyojanāni pahīyanti, anusayā byantīhonti.
an4.170:4.4.eng: By doing so, they give up the fetters and eliminate the underlying tendencies.

an4.170:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu samathavipassanaṃ yuganaddhaṃ bhāveti.
an4.170:5.1.eng: Another mendicant develops serenity and discernment in conjunction.

an4.170:5.2.pli: Tassa samathavipassanaṃ yuganaddhaṃ bhāvayato maggo sañjāyati.
an4.170:5.2.eng: As they do so, the path is born in them.

an4.170:5.3.pli: So taṃ maggaṃ āsevati bhāveti bahulīkaroti.
an4.170:5.3.eng: They cultivate, develop, and make much of it.

an4.170:5.4.pli: Tassa taṃ maggaṃ āsevato bhāvayato bahulīkaroto saṃyojanāni pahīyanti, anusayā byantīhonti.
an4.170:5.4.eng: By doing so, they give up the fetters and eliminate the underlying tendencies.

an4.170:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhuno dhammuddhaccaviggahitaṃ mānasaṃ hoti.
an4.170:6.1.eng: Another mendicant’s heart is seized by restlessness to realize the teaching.

an4.170:6.2.pli: Hoti so, āvuso, samayo yaṃ taṃ cittaṃ ajjhattameva santiṭṭhati sannisīdati ekodi hoti samādhiyati.
an4.170:6.2.eng: But there comes a time when their mind is stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.

an4.170:6.3.eng: The path is born in them.

an4.170:6.4.pli: So taṃ maggaṃ āsevati bhāveti bahulīkaroti.
an4.170:6.4.eng: They cultivate, develop, and make much of it.

an4.170:6.5.pli: Tassa taṃ maggaṃ āsevato bhāvayato bahulīkaroto saṃyojanāni pahīyanti, anusayā byantīhonti.
an4.170:6.5.eng: By doing so, they give up the fetters and eliminate the underlying tendencies.

an4.170:7.1.pli: Yo hi koci, āvuso, bhikkhu vā bhikkhunī vā mama santike arahattappattiṃ byākaroti, sabbo so imehi catūhi maggehi, etesaṃ vā aññatarenā”ti.
an4.170:7.1.eng: All of the monks and nuns who declare in my presence that they have attained perfection, did so by one or other of these four paths.”
